text: you might think the budget doesn't
affect you but it does because it's all
about your money it's when the
Chancellor who's responsible for
Britain's money and economy tells us how
he plans to spend our taxes over the
next 12 months how much is spent on the
services that we all use is decided in
the budget how much is spent on your
local school or college for your
education how much money your local
hospital gets for care when you need it
and how much is spent on building new
homes these are just some of the big
policies which are an iced so much of
the budget affects what things cost lots
of people will be waiting to see if
there's any change in the price of beer
wine cider or spirits well the price of
petrol go up we'll tobacco prices be
affected the Chancellor decides all of
it how much we get paid can also be
affected by the budget because any
changes to the income tax rate are
always announced by the Chancellor now
if the income tax rate has to go up you
could be bringing home less money at the
end of the month because you're paying
more tax but if the rate was to come
down you could be bringing home more
money and the amount of money you earn
before you have to start paying taxes
can also change the money you pay in
taxes is what the Chancellor will spend
and his challenge will be to make the
cash go far enough now in the budget
he'll also tell us how the economy is
doing and if he needs to borrow any more
money just think of it as a little bit
like your own weekly budget except this
one is for the whole country
you
